From	time	to	time,	I	refer	to	and	comment	on	the	views	expressed	by	Mr	Oleh	Beketov,	who	has	provided	a	number	of	expert	reports	on	Ukrainian	law	on	behalf	of	the	JSC	Commercial	Bank	PrivatBank	(the	"Claimant"	(the	"Bank"))	at	 earlier	 stages	 of	 the	 proceedings.	The	fact	 that	 I	 do	 not	 address	 any	particular	point	made	by	Mr	Beketov	in	his	reports	does	not	mean	that	I	agree	with	what	he	says.	II. SUMMARY	OF	CONCLUSIONS	Question	1.	Which,	if	any,	of	the	agreements	referred	to	at	paragraph	53	of	the	List	of	Issues	(the	“Disputed	Transactions”)	were	sham	or	mock	transactions	(under	Article	235(1)	of	the	Civil	Code),	or	contrary	to	Ukrainian	public	policy	(pursuant	to	Article	228(1)	of	the	Civil	Code)?	Are	they	valid,	void	or	voidable?	15. Article	235	of	the	Civil	Code,	Law	of	Ukraine	No.	435-IV	dated	16	January	2003	(the	 "Civil	 Code")	applies	 to	 so-called	 mock	 transactions,	 i.e.	 transactions	which	have	a	particular	form	but	in	fact	are	intended	to	conceal	a	different	type	of	transaction.	Article	235(2)	provides	that	where	the	parties	enter	into	a	 mock	 transaction,	 their	 rights	 and	 obligations	 are	 regulated	 by	 the	 rules	
C2/1/7
	
8		applicable	 to	 the	 transaction	 they	 have	 actually	 made,	 not	 the	 transaction	which	they	purported	to	make.	Mock	transactions	are	thus	neither	void	nor	voidable	in	themselves.		16. On	 the	 facts	 pleaded	 by	 the	 Claimant,	I	 do	 not	 see	 how	 the	Disputed	Transactions	can	be	characterised	as	mock	transactions.	The	Claimant	has	not	specified	what	transactions	it	contends	the	parties	actually	made	which	the	court	 could	 give	 effect	 to	 instead	 of	 the	 agreements	 which	 the	 parties	purported	 to	 make.	 To	 the	 extent	 that	 the	 Claimant	maintains	 that	 the	transactions	 were	 intended	 to	 cover	 up	 the	 alleged	 “misappropriation”	 of	funds,	that	would	not	engage	Article	235	since	it	is	of	the	essence	of	Article	235	that	the	true	transaction	which	the	parties	intended	to	make,	and	which	the	court	will	recognise	as	having	been	made,	is	a	lawful	type	of	transaction	subject	to	particular	rules	which	the	court	can	apply.	The	misappropriation	of	funds	is	not	a	legitimate	type	of	transaction	regulated	by	the	Civil	Code,	so	Article	235	cannot	operate	in	such	circumstances.		17. Article	228	of	the	Civil	Code	provides	that	transactions	which	violate	public	policy	are	void.	The	threshold	for	a	violation	of	public	policy	is	high,	and	is	not	satisfied	simply	because	a	contract	is	not	intended	to	be	performed,	or	even	where	one	or	both	parties	have	an	unlawful	purpose,	but	only	when	a	contract	strikes	at	the	essential	foundations	of	the	rule	of	law.	Accordingly,	while	it	is	ultimately	 a	 question	 of	 fact	whether	 Article	 228	 applies	 to	 a	 particular	transaction,	 I	 do	not	 consider	 that	 a	 Ukrainian	 court	 would	 find	 it	 to	 be	applicable	in	the	circumstances	of	this	case.		18. In	addition,	and	in	any	event,	where	the	validity	of	a	contract	is	disputed,	the	court	 can	 only	 determine	 that	 the	 contract	 is	 invalid	 if	 the	 parties	 to	the	contract	 are	 before	 the	 court.	 Otherwise,	 any	 judgment	 will	 be	 legally	unsound	 because	 it	 will	 have	 the	 effect	 of	 determining	 the	 rights	 and	obligations	of	parties	not	before	the	court.	It	would	therefore	not	be	open	to	a	Ukrainian	court	to	find	the	Disputed	Transactions	invalid	in	the	absence	of	one	or	both	of	the	parties	to	the	agreements.

9		Question	 2.	 Were	 the	 Intermediary	 Loans	 void	 related-party	 lending	 on	 non-market	terms,	 contrary	 to	 Article	 52	 of	 the	 Law	 on	 Banks,	 and/or	 unauthorised	 significant	transactions	contrary	to	Article	70	of	the	JSC	Law?	19. Intermediary	Loans	entered	into	on	or	after	8	March	2015	would	be	voidable	(not	void)	transactions	pursuant	to	Article	52	of	the	Law	of	Ukraine	On	Banks	and	 Banking	 Activity	No.	2121-III	dated	07	 December	 2000	(the	 "Law	on	Banks")	if	(i)	the	borrowers	were	within	the	statutory	definition	of	related	parties	under	the	Law	on	Banks,	as	amended	with	effect	from	8	March	2015,	and	 (ii)	 the	 terms	 were	more	 favourable	to	 the	 borrowers	than	the	 terms	offered	on	the	market	by	other	banks	at	the	relevant	time,	including	if	they	were	 granted	 with	 no	 or	 inadequate	 security	 or	 at	 an	 unreasonably	 low	interest	rate.		20. However,	since	there	are	no	court	decisions	declaring	the	Intermediary	Loans	invalid	and	no	claims	have	been	brought	against	the	borrowers	to	have	them	declared	invalid,	the	Court	must	proceed	on	the	basis	that	they	are	valid	and	effective.		21. Article	70	of	the	Law	of	Ukraine	“On	Joint	Stock	Companies”	No.	514-VI	(the	"JSC	Law"),	in	force	from	1	May	2016,	required	that	transactions	with	a	value	of	 10-25%	 of	 the	 company’s	 assets	had	 to	 be	 approved	 by	 a	 company’s	supervisory	 board.	The	 Article,	 and	 the	 10-25%	 threshold,	apply	to	 each	transaction	(that	is,	each	Intermediary	Loan)	individually,	not	to	the	whole	complex	of	loans	combined.		22. If	and	to	the	extent	that	Article	70	applied,	and	the	Bank’s	counterparty	knew	that	the	supervisory	 board’s	approval	 had	 not	 been	 obtained,	 then	 the	Intermediary	Loans	would	be	voidable	(not	void),	provided	that	the	Bank	did	not	subsequently	approve	the	loans.		23. Where	a	company	has	fully	or	partly	performed	a	contract	without	objection	the	courts	are	likely	to	find	that	it	is	prevented	from	denying	the	validity	of	the	 contract,	 as	 this	 would	 be	 contrary	 to	 the	 prohibition	 on	inconsistent	conduct	and	abuse	of	rights.

10		Question	 3.	 In	 so	 far	 as	 they	 were	 funded	 (i)	 with	 money	 drawn	 down	 under	 other	Relevant	Loans,	Intermediary	Loans	and/or	New	Loans;	(ii)	with	Cash	Repayments	(by	which	we	mean	transfers	of	credit	from	a	bank	account	to	the	account	maintained	for	the	Relevant	Loan);	and/or	(iii)	by	way	of	the	Asset	Transfer,	were	any	of	the	purported	repayments	of	Relevant	Loans	invalid	as	a	matter	of	Ukrainian	law?	If	so,	on	what	basis	and	with	what	consequences?	24. No,	repayments	of	loans	cannot	be	“invalid”.	As	a	matter	of	Ukrainian	law,	only	a	transaction	can	be	valid	or	invalid,	and	the	repayment	of	loan	is	not,	and	cannot	be	characterised	as,	a	transaction.	The	crediting	of	funds	to	the	relevant	account	automatically	results	in	the	repayment	of	a	loan	pursuant	to	Article	1049(3)	of	the	Civil	Code.		25. Nor	is	there	any	basis	under	Ukrainian	law	on	which	repayments	of	loans	which	have	in	fact	occurred	can	be	“ignored”	or	“disregarded”.	If	a	loan	is	repaid	 using	 funds	 that	 were	 obtained	 unlawfully	 (for	 example,	 where	 a	borrower	has	deceived	a	lender	into	providing	further	funds),	this	in	no	way	affects	the	binding	effect	of	repayment	of	the	original	loans:	the	source	of	the	funds	used	to	repay	the	loan	is	irrelevant. should ensure they are familiar with CPR 35 and the Practice Direction (PD35). 
This guidance replaces the Protocol for the instruction of experts in civil claims

2.   Those instructing experts, and the experts, must also have regard to the 
objectives underpinning the Pre ಣAction Protocols to: ಣ 
a.  encourage the exchange of early and full information about the

The need for experts  
4. Those intending to instruct experts to give or prepare evidence for the 
purpose of civil proceedings should consider whether expert evidence is 
necessary, taking account of the principles set out in CPR Parts 1 and 35, and in 
particular whether “it is required to resolve the proceedings” (CPR 35.1).  
5. Although the court's permission is not generally required to instruct an 
expert, the court's permission is required before an expert’s report can be relied 
upon or an expert can be called to give oral evidence  (CPR 35.4).  
6. Advice from an expert before proceedings are started which the parties do 
not intend to rely upon in litigation is likely to be confidential; this guidance does 
not apply then. The same applies where, after the commencement of 
proceedings, experts are instructed only to advise (e.g. to comment upon a single 
joint expert’s report) and not to prepare evidence for the proceedings. The 
expert’s role then is that of an expert advisor.  
7. However this guidance does apply if experts who were formerly instructed 
only to advise, are later instructed as an expert witness to prepare or give 
evidence in the proceedings.  
8. In the remainder of this guidance, a reference to an expert means an 
expert witness to whom Part 35 applies.  
Duties and obligations of experts  
9. Experts always owe a duty to exercise reasonable skill and care to those 
instructing them, and to comply with any relevant professional code. However 
when they are instructed to give or prepare evidence for civil proceedings they 
have an overriding duty to help the court on matters within their expertise (CPR 
35.3). This duty overrides any obligation to  the person instructing or paying them. 
Experts must not serve the exclusive interest of those who retain them.  
10. Experts should be aware of the overriding objective that courts deal with 
cases justly and that they are under an obligation to assist the court in this 
respect. This includes dealing with cases proportionately (keeping the work and ANNEX B LETTER OF INSTRUCTIONS WITH SCHEDULES 1-3

Experts must provide opinions that are independent, regardless of the 
pressures of litigation. A useful test of  ‘ i n d e p e n d e n c e ’  i s  t h a t  t h e  e x p e r t  w o u l d  
express the same opinion if given the same  instructions by another party. Experts 
should not take it upon themselves to promote the point of view of the party 
instructing them or engage in the role of advocates or mediators.  
12.     Experts should confine their opinions to matters which are material to the 
disputes and provide opinions only in re lation to matters which lie within their 
expertise. Experts should indicate without delay where particular questions or 
issues fall outside their expertise.  
13. Experts should take into account all material facts before them. Their 
reports should set out those facts and any literature or material on which they 
have relied in forming their opinions. They should indicate if an opinion is 
provisional, or qualified, or where they  c o n s i d e r  t h a t  f u r t h e r  i n f o r m a t i o n  i s  
required or if, for any other reason, they are not satisfied that an opinion can be 
expressed finally and without qualification.  
14. Experts should inform those instructing them without delay of any change 
in their opinions on any material matter and the reasons for this (see also 
paragraphs 64-66).  
15. Experts should be aware that any failure to comply with the rules or court 
orders, or any excessive delay for which they are responsible, may result in the 
parties who instructed them being penalised in costs, or debarred from relying 
upon the expert evidence (see also paragraphs 89-92 ).
